Real sorry about that...  Mixed my JARs...  Here's the address:  http://pro=
tomatter.sourceforge.net/

Have a nice day,
Francois
  ----- Original Messa=
ge ----- 
  From: Simon Evans 
  To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com' 
  Sent: Tuesd=
ay, July 03, 2001 12:21 PM
  Subject: RE: [junit] printing my own debug mes=
sages


  i did not find Syslog...where can i find it?
    -----Original Me=
ssage-----
    From: Francois Beausoleil [mailto:fbos44@...]
    Se=
nt: Tuesday, July 03, 2001 9:05 AM
    To: junit@yahoogroups.com
    Subjec=
t: Re: [junit] printing my own debug messages


    Personnaly, I prefer Sy=
slog from www.clarkware.com.  JavaWorld (www.javaworld.com) had an article =
about best practices for it.

    What I like about Syslog (although I have=
 not used Log4J very much) is that I can start logging with just a line.  T=
he default values are fine for me - Output goes to the console.

    The on=
ly problem I have with that is that the results of the output are not mixed=
 with the results of the TestCase.  So, if I have lots of debugging message=
s, the output is not with the failure.  I have to work a bit to make it fit=
.  But it's usually paid off by finding another error or two :)

    Thanks=
,
    Francois
      ----- Original Message ----- 
      From: Jason Rogers=
 
      To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com' 
      Sent: Tuesday, July 03, 2001 9:3=
4 AM
      Subject: RE: [junit] printing my own debug messages


      I lo=
oked at that some time ago for some simple logging needs we had, and it
   =
   seemed really heavyweight.  Do you disagree?  Do you think it can be sca=
led
      down pretty easily?

          > 
          > I've check =
all the available documentation on whether there is a 
          > possibil=
ity to print my own debug output messages from a 
          > test case in =

          > a controlled way - ideally I would like to get them in a 
    =
      > "results.txt" like can be produced by the junit task in 
          =
> ant. It seems 
          > that this is not the way that I'm supposed to =
go, since 
          > there seems to 
          > be no option for that. 
=
          > 
          > Nevertheless, it would be nice to use the test cas=
e for debugging 
          > (until it works).
          > It there an opti=
on for that? 
          > 
          > Cheers, 
          >

ris
